int eat_space ( register char *  string,
register int  at 
)

returns index of first non-blank character in string, starting at at e.g., eat_space("0123 6",4) returns 6

Parameters:
string a C character string
at an index into 'string'
Returns:

int find ( char  s1[],
char  s2[] 
)

locate the first occurrence of string s2 within s1. behaves properly for null s1. returns -1 for no match.

Parameters:
s1 a C character string
s2 a C character string
Returns:
the index of the first occurence of s2 within s1, -1 if not found
int find_char_of ( char  s1[],
char  s2[] 
)

finds first occurrence of any character in s2 within s1. returns index of null terminator for no match (i.e., f_c_of("cat","dog") ==> 3 ( = strlen("cat"))).

Parameters:
s1 a C character string
s2 a C character string
Returns:
the index of the first occurence of any character in s2 in s1, -1 if not found

int gobble ( char *  target,
char *  string,
int  j 
)

gobble string if it matches target, ignoring blanks in string start at j, return index of first character past the end e.g, gobble(".true."," .true. ") returns 10 (index of the terminating zero

char* nscat ( int  n,
char *  s1,
  ... 
)

nscat(n,s1,...,sn) - concatenate n strings into a dynamically allocated blob, and return a pointer to the result. "n" must be equal to the # of strings. The n strings are freed with sfree(). The returned pointer should be freed with sfree().

Parameters:
n the number of strings to concatenate
s1 a variable number of C character strings
Returns:
a pointer to the concatenated strings
char* nssave ( int  n,
const char *const   s1,
  ... 
)

nssave(n,s1,...,sn) - concatenate n strings into a dynamically allocated blob, and return a pointer to the result. "n" must be equal to the # of strings. The returned pointer should be freed with sfree().

Parameters:
n the number of strings to concatenate
s1 a variable number of C character strings
Returns:
a pointer to the concatenated strings
char* rindex3 ( register char *  str,
register char  ch,
register char *  at 
)

rindex3 - like rindex, but takes a third argument, "at", which points at the location within the string "str" to begin looking for "ch". Basically, this avoids a strlen() every time we do a rindex().

Parameters:
str a C character string
ch a character
at a character
Returns:
the rightmost index of ch in str starting at 'at'

char* string_print ( char *  buf,
int  size,
va_list  arg_list 
)

Returns a temporary string made up from the sprintf() style variable arguments. The string is destroyed by the next call to this fuction.

Parameters:
buf a C character string storing the result
size the size of the buffer
arg_list a variable number of character strings
Returns:
the resulting string

int  his_length 
)

start an index into s1
his_length the max number of characters allowed in the substring
Returns:
